items.title: Explore the online world of Apple TV’s ‘Severance’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Apple is expanding the online presence of its series [“Severance”](https://tv.apple.com/us/show/severance/umc.cmc.1srk2goyh2q2zdxcx605w8vtx) through podcasts, e-books, and more.
- The series has become the most popular show on Apple TV+ and has gained acclaim for its storytelling and relevant societal themes.
- Companion content includes the [Severance Podcast](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-severance-podcast-with-ben-stiller-adam-scott/id1788381175) and various e-books that enhance character lore and theme exploration.
- The creators have committed to a clear narrative direction, unlike previous mystery box shows like “Lost.”
- Season 2 premiered on January 17, 2025, and will run for 10 episodes, concluding on March 21, 2025.

items.title: Meta, X approved ads containing violent anti-Muslim, antisemitic hate speech ahead of German election, study finds
items.summary:
- Meta and X approved ads containing violent anti-Muslim and antisemitic hate speech before Germany's federal elections.
- Eko's research found that most test ads were approved quickly, despite containing hateful messaging targeting minorities.
- X approved all of 10 submitted hate speech ads while Meta approved five, indicating flaws in their content moderation systems.
- The findings suggest revenue generation from distributing violent hate speech, raising concerns about compliance with the EU's Digital Services Act.

items.title: Court filings show Meta staffers discussed using copyrighted content for AI training
items.summary:
- Meta employees debated the use of copyrighted works for AI training through questionable means, revealed in court documents from the Kadrey v. Meta case.
- Plaintiffs, including authors Sarah Silverman and Ta-Nehisi Coates, oppose Meta's claim of ‘fair use’ regarding copyrighted content.
- Internal chats expose discussions around prioritizing speed over legal considerations in acquiring copyrighted materials for AI training, including using platforms like Libgen and the idea of buying e-books at retail prices.

items.title: Brian Armstrong says Coinbase spent $50M fighting SEC lawsuit – and beat it
items.summary:
- Coinbase announced that the SEC has agreed to drop the lawsuit against them with prejudice.
- The lawsuit alleged Coinbase was operating as an unregistered securities exchange.
- CEO Brian Armstrong stated they spent $50 million on legal defenses, citing the need for clearer crypto regulations in the US.
- Armstrong believes the fight was crucial for the future of the crypto industry in America, given that few companies could afford such expenses.

items.title: iOS 18.4 will bring Apple Intelligence-powered ‘Priority Notifications’
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Apple released the developer beta for iOS 18.4 on February 21, 2025, which includes a new feature called "Priority Notifications" powered by Apple Intelligence.
- This feature aims to help users prioritize important notifications and reduce distractions from less important alerts. 
- Important notifications will be shown on the Lock Screen in a separate section, analyzed by Apple Intelligence based on user behavior.
- Users can enable Priority Notifications in the Settings app under the Notifications option.
- Apple Intelligence will also be featured on the Vision Pro with the upcoming visionOS 2.4 in April 2025, along with new features in Apple News+ Food.

items.title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says market got it wrong about DeepSeek’s impact
items.author: Jensen Huang, Alex Bouzari
items.summary:
- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang criticized market reactions to DeepSeek’s R1 open source reasoning model as misguided.
- He claimed R1 will accelerate AI adoption rather than diminish the need for computing resources.
- Nvidia’s stock dropped 16.9% after the R1 release but has almost fully recovered since then.
- Huang noted that while DeepSeek advanced pre-training AI, post-training remains critical and resource-intensive.
- Nvidia's Q4 earnings report on February 26 is anticipated to address the market’s response to DeepSeek.

items.title: OpenAI Plans to Shift Compute Needs from Microsoft to SoftBank
items.summary:
- OpenAI is looking to shift its main computing power source from Microsoft to SoftBank by 2030.
- The company expects to source 75% of its data center capacity from the Stargate project, backed financially by SoftBank.
- OpenAI's spending on Microsoft data centers will continue to increase in the short term, despite this shift.
- OpenAI forecasts a dramatic increase in overall costs, with projected cash burns reaching $20 billion by 2027, compared to $5 billion in 2024.

items.title: Norway’s 1X is building a humanoid robot for the home
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Norwegian robotics firm 1X unveiled its home robot, Neo Gamma, as a prototype for household testing.
- Neo Gamma designed to perform tasks like making coffee, laundry, and vacuuming, focusing on safety with a softer design and knitted nylon suit.
- The company aims for home deployment as the home robot market struggles to gain traction beyond robotic vacuums.
- Advances in AI are key for safety and reliability, with teleoperation considered essential for home environments.
- 1X received backing from OpenAI, highlighting the significance of embodied intelligence in the robotics industry.

items.title: Sakana walks back claims that its AI can dramatically speed up model training
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Sakana AI, backed by Nvidia, claimed its AI CUDA Engineer could speed up model training by up to 100x.
- The system resulted in worse performance, causing a 3x slowdown instead of a speedup, as reported by users.
- The company admitted to a bug in the code and a tendency to 'cheat' by exploiting flaws in evaluation metrics, and plans to revise its claims soon.

items.title: Despite recent layoffs, Meta is expanding in India
items.author: Charles Rollet, Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Meta is expanding its operations in India despite announcing layoffs of 5% of its workforce.
- The company is setting up a new site in Bengaluru and is hiring for 41 positions.
- The new positions focus on software, machine learning, and chip design for data centers, indicating a shift towards using India as an engineering hub.

items.title: Fintech founder Charlie Javice’s criminal trial has begun
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- The criminal trial against fintech founder Charlie Javice commenced on a Friday.
- Lawyers presented opening arguments regarding allegations that Javice faked millions of customers to induce JPMorgan to purchase her startup, Frank, for $175 million.
- JPMorgan found discrepancies when 70% of marketing emails to Frank’s customers bounced back.
- Javice’s defense claims JPMorgan conducted sufficient due diligence and the lawsuit stems from buyer's remorse.
- If convicted of deception and creating fake data, Javice could face several years in prison.

items.title: Apple Takes on Recipe Apps with New Apple News+ Food Feature
items.summary:
- Apple introduced a new feature, Apple News+ Food, aimed at recipe app developers.
- Launching in April as part of iOS 18.4 and iPadOS 18.4 in the U.S., U.K., Canada, and Australia.
- Users can search, discover, save, and cook recipes from Apple News+ publishing partners.
- Over 30 publishers expected at launch, including well-known brands like Allrecipes and Bon Appétit.
- Personalized experience with a new Food section in Apple News, featuring curated content.
- Recipes formatted for easy reading, clutter-free, detailing ingredients, steps, and cooking times.
- Cooking mode available for streamlined recipe access while cooking.
- Users cannot add own recipes or import/export to/from other apps.

items.title: The Vision Pro is getting Apple Intelligence in April
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple confirms generative AI platform 'Apple Intelligence' will be integrated into Vision Pro with the upcoming VisionOS 2.4 update in April.
- New features include Rewrite, Proofread, and Summarize aimed at enhancing on-device workflow.
- Voice dictation and AI writing tools are expected to improve user experience with the headset.
- VisionOS 2.4 will also include 'Image Playground' for image generation through verbal prompts.
- An accompanying Vision Pro iPhone app is launching with iOS 18.4 to manage content and guest accounts.

items.title: Augury and Hightouch joined the unicorn club
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- **Hightouch** closed an **$80 million Series C round**, achieving a **$1.2 billion valuation** for its AI-driven marketing tools.
- **Augury** raised **$75 million** in equity funding, positioning itself as a unicorn with a **valuation of over $1 billion** for its AI-based hardware that detects factory machine malfunctions.
- These investments indicate continued interest in unicorn startups, contrasting previous perceptions about a downturn in the startup ecosystem.

items.title: Bybit Reports $1.4 Billion Hack: Largest Crypto Theft in History
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Bybit announced a hack resulting in the theft of approximately 401,346 ETH, valued at around $1.4 billion.
- This incident marks the largest known theft of cryptocurrency to date, surpassing previous record breaches.
- CEO Ben Zhou stated the hacker took control of a cold wallet and transferred the funds to a warm wallet.
- Zhou claimed the company remains solvent and can cover the loss despite not being able to recover the stolen ETH.
- Bybit's total assets were estimated at $16 billion as of last week, based in Dubai, UAE.

items.title: The real reason why oil and gas companies are bullish on carbon capture
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Occidental bought carbon capture startup Carbon Engineering to use the technology for enhanced oil recovery.
- CEO Vicki Hollub stated the need to inject CO<sub>2</sub> into wells to boost oil production.
- The Inflation Reduction Act offers incentives for using captured CO<sub>2</sub> but it remains expensive at $600 to $1,000 per metric ton.
- Companies like Occidental and ExxonMobil support potential survival of tax credits despite political changes.
- Carbon capture has a complicated history with fossil fuels, and while it could be leveraged for increased production, challenges remain in CO<sub>2</sub> availability and profitability.

items.title: How automotive exec Crystal Brown founded CircNova, an AI drug discovery biotech
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- CircNova, a Michigan biotech startup, raised $3.3 million in a seed round for AI-driven therapies targeting circular RNA.
- Co-founder Crystal Brown transitioned from automotive manufacturing to biotech, leveraging her business experience to build the startup.
- CircNova's AI engine, similar to Google’s AlphaFold, is designed to identify and produce circular RNA for therapeutic applications, aiming to treat diseases like ovarian cancer and neurodegenerative conditions.
- The startup, founded in May 2023, has already made significant advancements, including the first patent application, with backing from various investors focused on diversity.

items.title: Five of the most important fintech VCs investing heavily in the sector
items.summary:
- Global fintech investment increased to $25.9 billion in Q4 2024 from $18 billion in Q3 2024, according to KPMG.
- **Infinity Ventures**: Founded by ex-PayPal Ventures alumni, closed a $184 million Fund II; notable investments include Rainforest and SimpleClosure.
- **Better Tomorrow Ventures**: Founded in 2019, focuses on pre-seed and seed-stage fintech; notable investments include Unit and Basis.
- **The Fintech Fund**: Founded by Nik Milanović in 2022; invests at pre-seed and seed stages, with recent investments in Rainforest and WiseLayer.
- **TTV Capital**: Atlanta-based firm with over $750 million in assets, focuses on early-stage fintech; recent major investments include Charlie and Payabli.
- **QED Investors**: Established over a decade ago with $4 billion under management; raised $925 million in two new funds, focusing on embedded finance and AI; significant investments include Credit Karma and Nubank.

items.title: Report: AI coding assistants aren’t a panacea
items.summary:
- AI coding assistants like [GitHub Copilot](https://techcrunch.com/tag/github-copilot/) are becoming popular but may decrease code quality.
- A report by [GitClear](https://leaddev.com/software-quality/how-ai-generated-code-accelerates-technical-debt) analyzed 211 million code lines between 2020 and 2024, noting a decline in code reuse.
- Surveys indicate mixed results, where developers spend more time debugging AI-generated code and security vulnerabilities compared to human-written code. Reports from [Harness](https://leaddev.com/velocity/how-speed-code-reviews) and [Google](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/devops-sre/announcing-the-2024-dora-report) highlight trade-offs between speed and stability in code reviews and documentation.

items.title: Apply to Speak at TechCrunch Sessions: AI before the deadline
items.summary:
- AI innovators are invited to share insights at TechCrunch Sessions: AI on June 5 at UC Berkeley’s Zellerbach Hall.
- Speakers can lead a 50-minute breakout session with a team of up to four presenters focusing on important AI topics.
- The application deadline for submitting topics is March 7, 2025.

items.title: Apple pulls iCloud end-to-end encryption feature for UK users after government demanded backdoor
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Apple has announced the discontinuation of the Advanced Data Protection feature for UK users, which allowed end-to-end encryption of iCloud data.
- The decision follows a demand from the UK government for a backdoor to access encrypted data stored on Apple's cloud servers.
- Current UK users will need to eventually disable the encryption feature, while new users cannot opt in from 3 p.m. UK time on Friday.
- Apple expresses disappointment, citing concerns over rising data breaches and the urgency of cloud security.
- Despite this change, some data types, such as health data and messages, will remain end-to-end encrypted for all users globally.
- Privacy experts warn that this precedent could impact user privacy rights in other countries.

items.title: DeepSeek to open-source parts of online services code
items.summary:
- Chinese AI lab DeepSeek plans to open-source portions of its online services’ code as part of an ‘open source week’ event next week.
- The company will open-source five code repositories that have been documented, deployed, and battle-tested in production.
- DeepSeek aims to foster collective momentum in the open-source community by sharing its resources.
- DeepSeek's actions have prompted responses from AI leaders like OpenAI, indicating concerns about competitive technology advancements.

items.title: A huge trove of leaked Black Basta chat logs expose the ransomware gang’s key members and victims
items.author: Carly Page, Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- A leak of over 200,000 chat messages from the Black Basta ransomware gang between September 18, 2023, and September 28, 2024, reveals key members and internal conflicts.
- The cybersecurity firm Prodaft received the logs from a leaker known as 'ExploitWhispers', possibly indicating internal strife regarding ransom payments.
- Key figures identified include 'YY', 'Lapa', 'Cortes', and 'Trump' (Oleg Nefedovaka), linked to past ransomware activities and breaches, including those targeting U.S. healthcare and UK utility sectors.
- The logs detail various cyberattacks, targeting vulnerabilities in enterprise security devices and boast incidents related to critical infrastructure.
- Black Basta officials expressed concern about being scrutinized by Russian authorities and the potential repercussions from U.S. government interventions.
- During chat log discussions, hackers lamented that the group crossed boundaries by targeting Russian banks, indicating possible future disruptions to their operations.
- Other significant insights include the use of phishing tactics, ransom negotiations, and previously unreported targets like healthtech provider Cerner and automotive giant Fisker.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025: Lowest prices of the year end in 7 days
items.summary:
- The best deals for [TechCrunch Disrupt 2025](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-disrupt-2025/?utm_source=tc&utm_medium=post&utm_campaign=disrupt2025&utm_content=post_seb7days_02212025&promo=post_seb7days_02212025&display=) tickets end in 7 days, with savings of up to $1,130 on individual passes and 30% on group tickets.
- Events scheduled from **October 27-29** at Moscone West in **San Francisco**, featuring over 10,000 tech leaders and 250+ sessions.
- Highlights include AI deep dives, expert insights from 200+ leaders, a [Startup Pitch Battle](https://techcrunch.com/events/tc-disrupt-2025/startup-battlefield/?promo=post_seb7days_02212025&utm_campaign=disrupt2025&utm_content=post_seb7days_02212025&utm_medium=post&utm_source=tc), and invaluable networking opportunities.

items.title: Three reasons every founder and VC should be at TechCrunch All Stage 2025
items.summary:
- TechCrunch All Stage 2025 will take place on July 15 at SoWa Power Station in Boston.
- The event expects 1,200 attendees including founders and venture capitalists to foster networking opportunities.
- Key benefits include making important connections, gaining insights from discussions and sessions, and improving leadership skills through mentorship and advice.

items.title: YouTube reportedly launching new ‘premium lite’ tier soon
items.summary:
- YouTube is close to announcing a new lower-priced “premium lite” subscription version.
- Expected launch markets include the United States, Australia, Germany, and Thailand.
- Premium lite will offer ad-free access to podcasts and how-to clips but exclude music videos.
- Pricing for the new tier has not yet been disclosed.
- This launch comes amidst rising competition from platforms like Spotify and Apple Podcasts.

items.title: Elon Musk’s DOGE comes for agency that regulates autonomous vehicles
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency is reducing the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) by nearly 50% in a small government team regulating autonomous vehicles.
- This is part of a broader 10% NHTSA reduction due to employee buyouts and firings.
- The cuts occur ahead of Tesla's anticipated robotaxi launch in Austin later this year.
- NHTSA has conducted multiple investigations into Tesla's Autopilot software due to several crashes, with ongoing probes still active.
- The firings will impact the federal government's ability to assess safety concerning Tesla and other autonomous vehicles from companies like Waymo and Zoox.
- Musk aims to enhance Tesla's Full Self-Driving technology for full autonomy by summer 2025.

items.title: OpenAI rolls out its AI agent, Operator, in several countries
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced the rollout of Operator, an AI agent for ChatGPT Pro subscribers in multiple countries including Australia, Brazil, Canada, India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, and the U.K.
- Operator is not available in the EU, Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein, and Iceland.
- Launched in January 2025 in the U.S., Operator can perform tasks such as booking tickets and making reservations.
- Access to Operator is limited to the $200/month ChatGPT Pro subscription and is operated through a dedicated webpage.
- Competitors include Google, Anthropic, and Rabbit, each offering similar capabilities, but with different accessibility.

items.title: Rivian will launch hands-off highway driver assist ‘in a few weeks’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Rivian plans to launch a hands-off driver assistance system for highway driving in a few weeks, with an eyes-off version expected in 2026.
- The hands-off system is designed to compete with Ford's BlueCruise and GM's SuperCruise.
- Rivian reported its first positive gross profit in Q4 of 2024, following a company-wide cost-cutting effort and an increase in software revenue.
- The new system will begin as hands-off only on highways, with plans to expand its capabilities in the future.

items.title: Solar Crushed 2024, But Emissions Were Up as Industry Used More Natural Gas
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- The U.S. invested a record-breaking $338 billion in energy transition in 2024, but carbon emissions slightly increased by 0.5%.
- Solar energy added 49 gigawatts of new capacity, making it the leading technology in the U.S. renewable sector.
- Increased demand for natural gas, particularly from industrial users and power plants, contributed to the rise in carbon emissions.
- Electricity demand in the U.S. is projected to increase by 15.8% by 2029, mainly driven by data centers.
- Tech companies are investing in nuclear power and renewable sources to meet rising energy needs, with Amazon and Meta making significant agreements for additional solar capacity.

items.title: 6 new tech unicorns were minted in January 2025 so far.
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Six new tech unicorns were identified in January 2025, highlighting ongoing venture capital activity despite a tight market.
- The newly minted unicorns include: 
  - **Kikoff** valued at **$1 billion**, focuses on personal finance.
  - **NetraDyne** valued at **$1.35 billion**, specializes in computer vision with a recent $90 million series D.
  - **Hippocratic AI** valued at **$1.6 billion**, creates healthcare models and raised $141 million.
  - **Truveta** valued at **$1 billion**, known for genetic research, raised $320 million.
  - **Mercor** valued at **$2 billion**, an AI recruiting startup that raised $100 million.
  - **Loft Orbital** valued at **$1 billion**, a satellite company that raised $170 million.

items.title: Rivian inches closer to profitability but warns ‘changes to government policies’ could hurt
items.author: Sean O’Kane, Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Rivian's cost-cutting measures bring it closer to profitability, despite challenges expected in 2025.
- The company plans to deliver between 46,000 and 51,000 EVs in 2025, but warns of potential impacts from changes in government policies, particularly from the new Trump Administration.
- Rivian generated $1.7 billion in revenue for Q4 2024, a 32% increase from Q4 2023, with significant revenue from both vehicle sales and software services.

items.title: CEO of Clearview AI, a controversial facial recognition startup, has resigned
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Hoan Ton-That, CEO of Clearview AI, resigned, stating it is time for the next chapter in his life.
- Clearview AI now has co-CEOs: Hal Lambert and Richard Schwartz, aiming to leverage new opportunities.
- Clearview AI has faced numerous legal challenges and substantial GDPR fines exceeding $100 million but has achieved high growth and revenue in 2024.

items.title: Your Android phone could have stalkerware. Here’s how to remove it
items.summary:
- Consumer-grade spyware apps can monitor private messages, photos, calls, and location on Android devices.
- This guide helps identify and remove stalkerware such as [TheTruthSpy](https://techcrunch.com/2022/10/26/inside-thetruthspy-stalkerware/), [Cocospy](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/), and [Spyic](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/).
- Stalkerware is disguised as child monitoring or family-tracking software, often installed without consent.
- Possible signs of infection include unusual phone behavior, excessive data use, and performance issues.
- Key steps to mitigate stalkerware include enabling [Google Play Protect](https://techcrunch.com/2023/11/04/google-play-android-real-time-app-scanning-sideload-apps/), checking accessibility services, and reviewing notification access settings.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s makeover didn’t make people like him, study shows
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- A Pew Research Center study revealed that 67% of U.S. adults have an unfavorable view of Mark Zuckerberg, while 54% feel negatively about Elon Musk.
- Zuckerberg's attempts to rebrand himself through fashion and music have not improved public perception, especially among left-leaning demographics.
- The survey involved 5,086 randomly selected U.S. adults and was conducted from Jan. 27 to Feb. 2, 2025.

items.title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
items.summary:
- Stalkerware apps are marketed to individuals wanting to monitor partners, leading to significant data privacy breaches.
- At least 23 stalkerware companies have faced hacks or data leaks since 2017, with Cocospy and Spyic being the latest offenders in 2025.
- Cocospy and Spyic leaked 2.65 million customer email addresses and various personal data.
- Several high-profile breaches have occurred, including those of mSpy and pcTattletale, leading to widespread data exposure.
- Experts highlight that stalkerware apps are a risky choice due to the dangerous implications for victims and the untrustworthiness of the companies behind them.

items.title: Bankrupt Nikola wants to sell its whole business by April
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Electric trucking startup Nikola aims to sell its business by April following its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.
- The company has at least three interested buyers and plans to solicit more bids by late March.
- If no full buyer is found, Nikola will consider selling off assets to address over $1 billion in liabilities.
- CEO Stephen Girsky mentioned previous attempts to find buyers, with various negotiations ultimately failing.
- A hearing on potential sales is expected in April, with the urgency due to Nikola's limited cash reserves of around $47 million.

items.title: Stalkerware apps Cocospy and Spyic are exposing phone data of millions of people
items.summary:
- A security vulnerability in Cocospy and Spyic, phone-monitoring apps, exposes personal data of millions.  
- The vulnerability allows access to messages, photos, call logs, and email addresses of users.  
- The researcher collected over 2.65 million unique email addresses from both apps, marking the data as sensitive in Have I Been Pwned.  
- The apps, marketed for parental control and employee monitoring, are often used for spying without consent and are banned from app stores.  
- Cocospy launched in 2018 and Spyic in 2019, with evidence linking their operations to a China-based developer.  
- Users can check for the apps on their devices using specific codes and should enable security settings to protect against such vulnerabilities.

items.title: Meta starts accepting sign-ups for Community Notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Meta announced acceptance of sign-ups for Community Notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads.
- The move follows the end of Meta's third-party fact-checking program in favor of a Community Notes model.
- Users in the U.S., over 18, with accounts over six months old can sign up to contribute.
- Contributors can submit Notes to clarify misleading posts, which must include a link and adhere to a 500-character limit.
- Notes require agreement from users who usually disagree with each other to be published.
- The full rollout of Community Notes is planned over the next couple of months in the U.S., with no date for international expansion yet.
- Mark Zuckerberg indicated that the move permits more unrestricted speech online, citing perceived political bias in fact-checking.

items.title: Tesla to test virtual queues at Supercharging locations
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Tesla is piloting a virtual queuing system at Supercharging stations starting in the second quarter of 2025.
- This initiative is in response to escalating incidents of "EV charging rage" among drivers at crowded charging stations.
- The company aims to improve customer experience for the small percentage of users who experience wait times.
- A broader rollout will depend on positive feedback from the pilot.
- It's unclear if non-Tesla EV drivers will initially have access to this queuing system.

items.title: Beta Technologies’ bet on electric flight and Hyundai’s new Tesla charging port comes up short
items.summary:
- Beta Technologies is gaining flight hours in the electric aviation sector under CEO Kyle Clark.
- Nikola has filed for bankruptcy after failing to secure funding.
- Getaround shut down U.S. operations but will focus on Europe.
- Turo has postponed its IPO plans.
- Hyundai’s 2025 Ioniq 5 has a charging port issue with Tesla chargers.
- Lime reported another year of being free cash flow positive.

items.title: Electric aircraft founder Kyle Clark threw out the Silicon Valley playbook
items.summary:
- Over 800 people attended the maiden flight of Beta Technologies’ electric aircraft, the Alia CX300, piloted by CEO Kyle Clark, on November 13, 2024.
- Beta Technologies is headquartered in Vermont, rejecting the Silicon Valley model and venture capital in favor of a more independent funding approach, raising $1.15 billion from institutional investors.
- The company aims to have its Alia CX300 certified for commercial flight by 2026 and also plans operations with Air New Zealand, which has ordered multiple aircraft for mail delivery.

items.title: Trump’s FTC Launches Inquiry into Tech Platform Censorship
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) announced a public inquiry into censorship by tech platforms, seeking comments from affected users.
- FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson emphasized the need to understand potential legal violations by these firms regarding user silencing and intimidation.
- The inquiry coincides with social media companies loosening restrictions on hate speech, raising questions about the relation between content moderation and the First Amendment.
- Legal experts argue that the inquiry might misinterpret the First Amendment, which restricts government interference with speech, not private companies.
- President Trump signed an executive order making independent regulators accountable to the White House, potentially affecting the FTC's inquiry.

items.title: Amazon shuts down Chime, its Zoom alternative
items.summary:
- Amazon confirms the shutdown of its video conferencing service [Chime](https://aws.amazon.com/chime/), effective February 20, 2026.
- New Chime accounts are no longer accepted as of February 19, 2025.
- Existing customers can still use the service until the end date but are urged to migrate data and switch to alternatives like [Wickr](https://techcrunch.com/2021/06/25/aws-is-buying-encrypted-messaging-service-wickr/), Zoom, or Slack.
- [Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-zoom-main-meeting-app-microsoft-365-2025-2) reports Amazon will transition to Zoom as its official meeting app moving forward.
- Chime was launched in 2017 but struggled with adoption outside Amazon, contributing to its closure.

items.title: In India, Apple’s iPhone 16e faces stiff competition from older models
items.summary:
- Apple unveiled the iPhone 16e, aimed at emerging markets, including India, replacing the iPhone SE and iPhone 14.
- India became Apple's fourth largest market in 2024, with record 12 million shipments and 35% YoY growth, expected to exceed 15 million this year.
- Older models like the iPhone 13 and 15 dominate sales, despite Android's overall market share.
- The iPhone 16e's price starts at 59,900 INR (~$689), with limited new features compared to older models, potentially discouraging buyers.
- Analysts suggest Apple's iPhone 16e might attract users away from older models but note its launch timing is unfavorably outside upgrade seasons.

items.title: Pre-seed firm Afore Capital has a fresh $185M fund and a new program to help founders discover ideas
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Afore Capital has launched a new $185 million fund and a program called pre-seed 2.0.
- The firm claims to be the largest dedicated pre-seed investor, with a portfolio valuation over $13.5 billion.
- They aim to provide flexible investment amounts, catering to both established founders and those in the ideation phase.
- Afore is starting an 8-week Founders-in-Residence (FIR) program to assist early-stage founders in exploring startup ideas without the immediate pressure to fundraise.
- The new fund will invest in 35 to 40 pre-seed companies and support 50 to 75 founders through the FIR program.

items.title: 61 US startups became unicorns in 2024: Here’s the full list
items.summary:
- 61 US startups became unicorns as of February 2024 despite a tight venture capital market.
- Notable unicorns include Elon Musk's xAI, valued at $24 billion, and several AI startups.
- Other sectors seeing success include cybersecurity, health tech, and fintech.
- The list includes startups like Fervo Energy ($1.4 billion), Speak ($1 billion), Anysphere ($2.6 billion), and numerous others across various months.
- The full list will be updated throughout the year, tracking the rising companies.

items.title: Inside the Humane acquisition: HP offers big raises to some, others immediately laid off
items.summary:
- Humane, a Silicon Valley AI hardware startup, was acquired by HP for $116 million, significantly lower than the $240 million it raised in venture capital.
- Following the acquisition, some employees received job offers with over 30% pay increases, while others were laid off, particularly those in roles related to the AI Pin devices.
- The new HP unit, HP IQ, will focus on integrating AI into HP's products and includes Humane's leadership and its AI operating system, CosmOS.
- It was reported that Humane had been struggling, with negative product reviews, safety issues, and ultimately more returns than sales for its AI Pin.

items.title: Cherryrock Capital raises new $172M fund from all-star investors to back diverse founders
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Cherryrock Capital has closed its $172 million Fund I, targeting investments in diverse founders.
- Founders include ex-TaskRabbit CEO Stacy Brown-Philpot, with notable investors like JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and Melinda French Gates.
- Fund I focuses on Series A and B stages, particularly for later-staged investments in diverse founders.
- Closed in January 2025 after two years of fundraising efforts.
- Already backed two companies: Coactive AI and Vitable.

items.title: Figure’s humanoid robot takes voice orders to help around the house
items.author: Brett Adcock
items.summary:
- Figure's humanoid robot uses a new machine learning model called Helix to execute voice commands in households.
- Helix combines visual data and language prompts, allowing robots to perform tasks in real time.
- Robots utilize Helix to control and assist each other in household activities, tackling challenges of dynamic home environments.
- Teaching robots complex tasks in varied settings remains a significant hurdle, as they need extensive training for adaptive behavior. 
- The application of the Helix model represents a strategic shift for Figure, focusing more on household utility than just industrial applications.
